questions.text: During morning rounds at the psychiatry ward, you ask a patient with schizophrenia if he has taken his medication. He replies with "Yes, I have taken my medication. The president of America is Joe Biden. My best friend is getting married tomorrow ..." and so on. He continues slowly, and none of the thoughts are related to each other. Which category of thought disorder does this fall under?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient with schizophrenia jumping from one thought to another without relevance indicates derailment/ loosening of associations of thought, which is a disorder of form of thought, as per Fish's classification of thought disorders.

Derailment/ Loosening of associations: A change in the train of thought that is characteristic of schizophrenic thinking. There is no logical sequence to the progression of thoughts, and it manifests as unrelated and unconnected ideas shifting from one subject to another. Patients with this disorder are unable to communicate efficiently.

Related Pearl: Classification of disorders of thought

questions.text:
Match the following disorders of perception with their examples.
Perceptual disorder Example
1. Hallucinations A. Objects in the surroundings appear foggy and distorted
2. Derealization B. Perceiving a rope as a snake
3. Illusion C. A man thinks he's a robot
4. Depersonalization D. Hearing the voice of a dead relative
questions.solution:
The option showing the correctly matched disorders of perception with their examples is 1-D, 2-A, 3-B, and 4-C.

Perceptual disorder Example
1. Hallucinations D. Hearing the voice of a dead relative
2. Derealization A. Objects in the surroundings appear foggy and distorted
3. Illusion B. Perceiving a rope as a snake
4. Depersonalization C. A man thinks he's a robot

The different disorders of perception are:

Illusion is the incorrect perception or misinterpretation of a sensory stimulus. It differs from hallucinations in that an actual external stimulus is present. 

Hallucination is the perception in the absence of any stimulus. It is characterized by the clarity and impact of a true perception but there is no external stimulus. The most frequently encountered hallucination in the psychiatric setting is auditory hallucinations. Other hallucinations include visual, tactile, olfactory, and gustatory hallucinations.

Depersonalization is the feeling of not being themselves or that something has changed. There is a feeling of unreality or detachment from one's whole self or from some aspects of self. This can be in terms of feelings (hypoemotionality), thoughts, or sensations. Sometimes it can be a diminished sense of agency, such as feeling robotic, or like an automaton.

Derealization refers to the feeling that one's environment has changed in some strange way that is difficult to describe. There is an experience of unreality or detachment with respect to surroundings. Individuals or objects can appear foggy, dreamlike, or visually distorted. 

Related Pearl: Disorders of thought and perception

DISORDERS OF THOUGHT

DISORDER OF STREAM OF THOUGHT

(A) Disorder of tempo

(i) Flight of Ideas

Continuous flow of rapid speech that jumps from topic to topic

  • "I like mangoes, the weather is nice, India is great"

(ii) Retardation of thinking

Slow speed of speech and a prolonged latent period before a response

  • "I went to the market (pause)......... the shop was closed"

(iii) Circumstantialities

Inclusion of irrelevant details and going on in a roundabout manner, but their thought ultimately reaches the answer

  • Doctor: "How did you get that bruise?"

  • Patient: "I woke up and had a cup of coffee, read the newspaper and went for a walk. It was a wonderful day in the park. I returned home and watched the TV. I took a nap in the afternoon after lunch. I slipped and fell in the bathroom. The fall gave me this bruise."

(iv) Clang associations

Jumping from one word to another irrelevant rhyming word

  • I am Sam...I like jam...I travel in a tram"

(B) Disorder of continuity

(i) Perseveration

Repetition of out of context words, phrases, or ideas beyond the point of relevance.

  • Q1. What's your name?: "Rahul"

  • Q2. Where are you from?: "Rahul"

  • Q3. How old are you?: "Rahul"

(ii) Thought blocking

A sudden disruption of thought or a break in the flow of ideas

  • "I went to the market (extreme silence)...................."

DISORDER OF FORM OF THOUGHT

(i) Tangentiality

In response to a question, the patient gives a reply that is appropriate to the general topic but does not answer the question exactly. The speech moves away from the actual answer.

  • Doctor: "Have you had any trouble sleeping lately?"
  • Patient: "I usually sleep in my bed, but now I'm sleeping on the sofa"

(ii) Derailment

A breakdown in both the logical connection between ideas and the overall sense of goal-directedness. The words make sentences, but the sentences do not make sense.

  • "Some people just don't understand why I had breakfast in America during the first world war"

(iii) Neologisms

Bringing in new words that do not exist.

  • The world is not 'gooder' for people like me"

(iv) Desultory thoughts

Speech is grammatically correct, however, sudden unrelated ideas force their way in from time to time.

  • My actual problem is that the people never understand me and my stomach feels like an empty bucket"

(v) Word salad

Using a mixture of unintelligible meaningless words and sentences

  • Tree bus rain food home car tiger"

DISORDER OF POSSESSION OF THOUGHT
A. Thought alienation

(i) Thought insertion

Thoughts are being inserted into the patient's mind and they recognize them as being foreign and coming from without any stimulus

  • "I have repeated thoughts of killing my neighbors and I believe aliens are putting these ideas into my head at night"

(ii) Thought withdrawal

Delusion that someone or something is removing from one's mind and the patient has no power over this.

  • "Lately, I am losing all my memories and I believe that the 'government agents' are stealing them when I go to sleep"

(iii) Thought broadcasting

Belief that one's thoughts are quietly escaping from one's mind and that other people might be able to access them and hear or see them.

  • "I believe my exact thoughts appear on the TV and the internet and I think I can broadcast them globally" 

(iv) Thought echo

Patient hears the 'echo' of his own thoughts in the form of a voice after he has made the thought.

  • "I thought of making a sandwich in the morning and surprisingly a voice, from nowhere, told me to make a sandwich out loud" 

 B. Obsessions and Compulsions

1. Obsessions

Recurrent and persistent thoughts, impulses. or images that cause distress to oneself.

  • Fear of dirt or contamination
  • Fear of becoming ill
  • Constant thoughts of a certain number
  • Need for symmetry or exactness
  • Worry about whether something has been done "right"
  • Forbidden sexual or religious thoughts

2. Compulsions

Repetitive behaviors or actions that the person feels driven to perform in response to an obsession

  • Washing hands
  • Blinking eyes
  • Counting items, such as currency
  • Checking to see if doors are locked
  • Arranging items in a certain way
  • Requiring constant approval from people around them

 
 DISORDER OF CONTENT OF THOUGHT

(i) Phobias

Persistent fear of an object or situation, typically disproportional to the actual danger posed, in which the sufferer goes to great lengths in avoiding it

  • Arachnophobia - fear of spider
  • Barophobia - fear of gravity
  • Cynophobia - fear of dogs
  • Hemophobia - fear of blood
  • Nosocomephobia - fear of hospitals

(ii) Religious preoccupations

Thoughts involving religious themes or subject matter.

  • "I get instructions from God on how to make my country great"

(iii) Ideas of hopelessness

Thoughts of complete despair where the patient strongly believes that the circumstances will never get better for him.

  • "I am never going to pass my final exams, no matter how hard I study"

(iv) Antisocial urges

Thoughts of indulging in some behaviors or actions that harm or lack consideration for the well being of others.

  • "I have these urges to go rob a bank or blackmail my neighbors for their money"

(v) Delusions

False beliefs that are strongly held and unchangeable in the face of refuting evidence and that are not consistent with the person's educational, social and cultural background.

The three main criteria for a belief to be considered a delusion are:

  • Certainty (held with complete confidence)
  • Incorrigibility (not changeable by proof to the contrary)
  • Impossibility or falsity of content (implausible, bizarre or patently untrue)
 DISORDERS OF PERCEPTIONS

  • Illusion: Misinterpretation of real external stimuli.

  • Hallucination: False sensory perception, externally.

  • Pseudohallucination: False sensory perception from within and having an insight.

  • Depersonalization: Feeling as if one is disconnected from reality, feeling detached from one's own thoughts and one's own physical body.

    "I sometimes drift into a dream-like state where I lose contact with my own self"

  • Derealization: Alteration in the perception or experience of the external world so that it seems unreal.

    "The world and everything around is nothing but just a dream"

Related Pearl: Types of delusions

THE TYPES OF DELUSIONS

Delusion of control

False belief that a person’s will, thoughts, or feelings are being controlled by external forces.

Delusion of grandeur or Megalomania 

Exaggerated conception of one’s importance, power, or identity.

Delusion of infidelity or morbid jealousy or Othello syndrome

False belief that one’s lover is unfaithful. Sometimes called pathological jealousy.

Delusion of love or erotomania

False belief that another person is in love with them. In De Clerambault syndrome, the woman believes that a man, frequently older and of higher status, is in love with her.

Delusion of misidentification 

Capgras syndrome: Belief that a familiar person has been replaced by an exact double i.e. an impostor.

Fregoli syndrome: Person holds a delusional belief that different people are in fact a single person who changes his or her appearance or is in disguise.

Nihilistic delusion 

False belief that oneself, others or the world, is non-existent or about to end. When nihilistic delusion is accompanied by ideas concerning bodily function failure e.g. putrefaction of intestine etc, it is called Cotard syndrome.

Delusion of infestation 

False belief that one is infested with small but visible organisms. As a monosymptomatic delusional disorder, this is called Ekbom syndrome. 

Delusion of persecution

The most common delusion. False belief of being harassed or persecuted.

Delusion of poverty

The person strongly believes they are financially incapacitated.

Delusion of reference

False belief that the behavior of others has a particular and unusual significance, usually of a negative nature. The person may falsely feel that others are talking about them (e.g. the people on television are talking to or about the person).  

Delusion of self-accusation

False feeling of remorse and guilt. Seen in depression with psychotic features.

questions.text:
A 24-year-old girl who goes to a party feels really drowsy and disoriented after consuming a non-alcoholic drink. A bystander says that she saw the girl's friend slip something into her drink. Which of the following drugs are most likely to be used for this purpose?
  1. Methamphetamine
  2. Ecstasy
  3. Ketamine
  4. Lysergic acid diethylamide
  5. Gamma hydroxybutyrate
questions.solution:
The given scenario with a drug being slipped into a drink without the knowledge of the person that results in drowsiness is suggestive of date-rape drug use. Among the given drugs, ketamine and gamma-hydroxybutyrate are date-rape drugs.

Drugs that are associated with dance clubs, bars, and all-night dance parties (raves) are known as club drugs. However, these drugs don't belong to the same class, and they have different effects. These drugs include:

  • Methamphetamine: accounts for most cases of overdoses and treatment admissions.
  • Methylenedioxymethamphetamine (MDMA) /Ecstasy 
  • LSD (Lysergic acid diethylamide)
  • Gamma hydroxybutyrate (GHB)
  • Ketamine
  • Flunitrazepam (Rohypnol/ roofies)

Date rape drugs are drugs that exhibit properties of sedation and disorientation and are often used in crowded places to drug someone for the purpose of sexual assault. People under the influence of these drugs usually do not remember the episode. Drugs that are used for this purpose are:

  • Gamma hydroxybutyrate 
  • Ketamine
  • Flunitrazepam

questions.text: A school girl is brought to the OPD by her worried mother with complaints of an urge to steal her classmate's pens and a feeling of gratification after doing so. The school headmistress says she was caught stealing one and was found with a bag full of pens. She is otherwise a good student and performs well. Which of the following is true about this condition?

choices.text: Stealing is not for personal gain
Stealing can be explained by a conduct disorder

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of kleptomania. It is characterized by recurrent impulses to steal objects not needed for personal use or for monetary value. 

DSM-5 criteria for kleptomania:

  • Recurrent failure to resist impulses to steal objects that are not needed for personal use or for their monetary value
  • Increasing sense of tension immediately before committing the theft
  • Pleasure, gratification, or relief at the time of committing the theft
  • The stealing is not committed to express anger or vengeance and is not in response to a delusion or a hallucination
  • The stealing is not explained by conduct disorder, a manic episode, or antisocial personality disorder

questions.text: A woman brings her 8-year-old son with the complaint that the child wakes up at night and walks around the room for about 15 minutes. Any attempt to communicate with him during the episode is unsuccessful. The child is unable to recall the episodes when he wakes up. Identify the brain waves that correspond to the stage of sleep in which this condition occurs.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario points towards a diagnosis of somnambulism (sleepwalking) which occurs during NREM stages 3 and 4 which is represented by high-frequency, slow delta waves. 

Somnambulism is a disorder of sleep arousal in which an individual arises from bed and carries out simple to complex motor activities without full consciousness. It occurs in the NREM phase of sleep. 

It is more commonly seen in children, with peak prevalence being between ages 4 to 8 years, and has a familial pattern. It usually resolves after adolescence and is rarely seen in adults. It may occur secondary to other sleep disorders like sleep apnea. Sleep deprivation, interruption of slow-wave sleep, alcohol consumption, and stress can exacerbate the condition.

During an episode of sleepwalking, the individual may sit up, attempt to walk, or perform semi purposeful actions. They have a blank expression and are unresponsive to communication. Waking them up is possible only with great difficulty. Upon awakening, they do not remember the sleepwalking episode (amnesia).

During the episode, patients can interact with the environment successfully (e.g., avoiding tripping over objects), but can also harm themselves (e.g., walking into the road).

Forms of somnambulism include:

  • Sleep-related eating - the individual may ingest food during the episode.
  • Sleep-related sexual behavior (sexsomnia) - the individual may engage in sexual activities during the episode

Management:

  • Reassurance
  • Maintaining patient safety during episodes
  • Avoiding sleep deprivation and alcohol consumption before going to bed
  • Antidepressants, relaxation techniques, and hypnosis may also be helpful.

questions.text: A first-year MBBS student came to OPD with intermittent episodes of the feeling of impending doom, accompanied by intense perspiration. Usually, the episodes occur prior to her exams. Which of the following agents has the most rapid onset of action against her condition?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis for this patient is panic disorder. Benzodiazepines have the most rapid onset of action in panic, with the onset happening often within the first week.

A panic attack is an abrupt surge of intense fear or intense discomfort. Recurrent panic attacks for more than one month are classified as panic disorder. Panic attacks can occur in mental disorders other than panic disorder, particu­larly in specific phobia, social phobia, and post-traumatic stress disorder.

Benzodiazepines such as alprazolam and lorazepam have been widely used for panic disorder. They are often used as a first agent while the serotonergic drug is up-titrated to therapeutic levels. Benzodiazepines are preferred for short-term therapy as long-term use can often lead to dependence and abuse.

Clinically, selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) and clomipramine are preferred over benzodiazepines, monoamine oxidase inhibitors (MAOIs), and tricyclic and tetracyclic drugs in terms of effectiveness, long-term therapy, and tolerance of adverse effects. 

Related Pearl: Panic disorder

DSM-5 criteria for panic disorder:

1.Recurrent and unexpected panic attacks with ≥ 4 of the following:

  • Palpitation
  • Sweating
  • Trembling or shaking
  • Shortness of breath of smothering sensation
  • Choking sensation
  • Chest pain or discomfort
  • Nausea or abdominal distress
  • Dizziness, light-headedness
  • Chills or heat sensation
  • Paraesthesia’s
  • Derealisation or depersonalisation
  • Fear of losing control or “going crazy”
  • Fear of dying  

 2. At least 1 attack followed by one or both of the following > 1 month:

  • Worry about additional panic attack or consequences
  • Changes in behaviour related to attacks (ex: avoidance)

3. Panic attack not attributable to substance abuse or another medical condition.

4. Panic attack not explained by another mental disorder.

Treatment of Panic disorder:

  • Immediate: benzodiazepines 
  • Long term: SSRI/ SNRI and or cognitive behavioural therapy

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman who had been diagnosed with major depression 3 years back has been on long-term therapy with antidepressants. She comes to the psychiatry OPD with complaints of reduced libido and difficulty in attaining orgasm. Which of the following drugs is she most likely consuming?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario showing a woman on long-term antidepressant therapy developing sexual dysfunction is most likely to have been caused by selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs). Sertraline is the SSRI among the given options.

All SSRIs cause sexual dysfunction, and it is the most common adverse effect of SSRIs associated with long-term treatment. Presenting adverse effects include anorgasmia, inhibited orgasm, and decreased libido. Other side effects of SSRIs include the following:

Anticholinergic Dry mouth, constipation, sedation

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient is brought to the hospital in a state of anxiety and agitation. He admits to taking a substance of abuse 1 hour back. He is aware of his surroundings but his attention is fleeting. He doesn't always answer questions. On examination, there was conjunctival injection, dry mouth, and tachycardia. Which among the following is the substance of abuse in this case?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features are suggestive of cannabis intoxication.

Cannabis is a commonly used psychoactive drug. Tetrahydrocannabinol is mainly responsible for the psychoactive effects. The plant is usually cut, dried, and rolled into cigarettes which are smoked. Some names for cannabis are marijuana, grass, pot, weed, and Mary Jane. Individuals who use cannabis every day for weeks to months are likely to become dependent.

Features associated with cannabis intoxication:

  • Conjunctival injection (red eye)
  • Dry mouth
  • Tachycardia
  • Increased appetite
  • Heightens user's sensitivities to external stimuli
  • Depersonalization and derealization
  • Impaired motor skill

Amotivational syndrome has been associated with long-term heavy use of cannabis. It is characterized by a person's unwillingness to persist in a task- at school, at work, or in any setting that requires prolonged attention or tenacity. Persons are described as becoming apathetic and anergic, usually gaining weight, and appearing slothful.

Other options :

Option B: Acute cocaine intoxication presents with delusions of persecution, paranoia, and suspiciousness. The patient also experiences a feeling of insects crawling under the skin, also known as cocaine bugs or formication, which is a characteristic feature of cocaine abuse. It is essential to differentiate acute cocaine intoxication from acute schizophrenia which it closely resembles. 

Option C: The signs of alcohol intoxication are slurred speech, dizziness, incoordination, unsteady gait, nystagmus, impairment in attention or memory, double vision, and stupor or coma. As these features are not pronounced in this patient it is unlikely that the patient is under the influence of alcohol.

Option D - Lysergic acid diethylamide (LSD) is a potent hallucinogen where intoxication presents with maladaptive behavioral and perceptual changes and physiological signs such as pupillary dilation, tachycardia, sweating, palpitations, blurring of vision, tremors, and incoordination. The patient in the given scenario does not have any perceptual change as he is aware of his surroundings.

Match the following phobias with their stimulus.
Phobia Stimulus
1. Mysophobia  A. Dogs
2. Agoraphobia  B. Strangers
3. Xenophobia

 C. Dirt and germs
4. Cynophobia  D. Open places
questions.solution:
The correctly matched set of phobias and their stimulus is 1-C, 2-D, 3-B, and 4-A.

A phobia can be described as a fear that is unreasonable and excessive for a given circumstance/stimulus. The phobic situation or the object is usually something that the person can avoid. 

Exposure or anticipation of contact with the situation/object triggers an anxiety reaction. This inadvertently leads to panic attacks in people who are susceptible. The person goes to great lengths to avoid this situation or object.

A few common phobias are listed below.

Acrophobia High places

Behavioral therapy is the most effective treatment for phobias. Insight-oriented therapy, virtual therapy, and exposure therapy are also used for the treatment of phobic disorders and specific phobias. β-receptor blockers can be used for the treatment of specific phobias, particularly if it associated with panic attacks. Benzodiazepines can also be used but the chronic nature of the disease limits its effect. Paroxetine and sertraline can be used to manage social anxiety.

  • Patient: "I woke up and had a cup of coffee, read the newspaper and went for a walk. It was a wonderful day in the park. I returned home and watched the TV. I took a nap in the afternoon after lunch. I slipped and fell in the bathroom. The fall gave me this bruise."

(iv) Clang associations

Jumping from one word to another irrelevant rhyming word

  • I am Sam...I like jam...I travel in a tram"

(B) Disorder of continuity

(i) Perseveration

Repetition of out of context words, phrases, or ideas beyond the point of relevance.

  • Q1. What's your name?: "Rahul"

  • Q2. Where are you from?: "Rahul"

  • Q3. How old are you?: "Rahul"

(ii) Thought blocking

A sudden disruption of thought or a break in the flow of ideas

  • "I went to the market (extreme silence)...................."

DISORDER OF FORM OF THOUGHT

(i) Tangentiality

In response to a question, the patient gives a reply that is appropriate to the general topic but does not answer the question exactly. The speech moves away from the actual answer.

  • Doctor: "Have you had any trouble sleeping lately?"
  • Patient: "I usually sleep in my bed, but now I'm sleeping on the sofa"

(ii) Derailment

A breakdown in both the logical connection between ideas and the overall sense of goal-directedness. The words make sentences, but the sentences do not make sense.

  • "Some people just don't understand why I had breakfast in America during the first world war"

(iii) Neologisms

Bringing in new words that do not exist.

  • The world is not 'gooder' for people like me"

(iv) Desultory thoughts

Speech is grammatically correct, however, sudden unrelated ideas force their way in from time to time.

  • My actual problem is that the people never understand me and my stomach feels like an empty bucket"

(v) Word salad

Using a mixture of unintelligible meaningless words and sentences

  • Tree bus rain food home car tiger"

DISORDER OF POSSESSION OF THOUGHT
A. Thought alienation

(i) Thought insertion

Thoughts are being inserted into the patient's mind and they recognize them as being foreign and coming from without any stimulus

  • "I have repeated thoughts of killing my neighbors and I believe aliens are putting these ideas into my head at night"

(ii) Thought withdrawal

Delusion that someone or something is removing from one's mind and the patient has no power over this.

  • "Lately, I am losing all my memories and I believe that the 'government agents' are stealing them when I go to sleep"

(iii) Thought broadcasting

Belief that one's thoughts are quietly escaping from one's mind and that other people might be able to access them and hear or see them.

  • "I believe my exact thoughts appear on the TV and the internet and I think I can broadcast them globally" 

(iv) Thought echo

Patient hears the 'echo' of his own thoughts in the form of a voice after he has made the thought.

  • "I thought of making a sandwich in the morning and surprisingly a voice, from nowhere, told me to make a sandwich out loud" 

 B. Obsessions and Compulsions

1. Obsessions

Recurrent and persistent thoughts, impulses. or images that cause distress to oneself.

  • Fear of dirt or contamination
  • Fear of becoming ill
  • Constant thoughts of a certain number
  • Need for symmetry or exactness
  • Worry about whether something has been done "right"
  • Forbidden sexual or religious thoughts

2. Compulsions

Repetitive behaviors or actions that the person feels driven to perform in response to an obsession

  • Washing hands
  • Blinking eyes
  • Counting items, such as currency
  • Checking to see if doors are locked
  • Arranging items in a certain way
  • Requiring constant approval from people around them

 
 DISORDER OF CONTENT OF THOUGHT

(i) Phobias

Persistent fear of an object or situation, typically disproportional to the actual danger posed, in which the sufferer goes to great lengths in avoiding it

  • Arachnophobia - fear of spider
  • Barophobia - fear of gravity
  • Cynophobia - fear of dogs
  • Hemophobia - fear of blood
  • Nosocomephobia - fear of hospitals

(ii) Religious preoccupations

Thoughts involving religious themes or subject matter.

  • "I get instructions from God on how to make my country great"

(iii) Ideas of hopelessness

Thoughts of complete despair where the patient strongly believes that the circumstances will never get better for him.

  • "I am never going to pass my final exams, no matter how hard I study"

(iv) Antisocial urges

Thoughts of indulging in some behaviors or actions that harm or lack consideration for the well being of others.

  • "I have these urges to go rob a bank or blackmail my neighbors for their money"

(v) Delusions

False beliefs that are strongly held and unchangeable in the face of refuting evidence and that are not consistent with the person's educational, social and cultural background.

The three main criteria for a belief to be considered a delusion are:

  • Certainty (held with complete confidence)
  • Incorrigibility (not changeable by proof to the contrary)
  • Impossibility or falsity of content (implausible, bizarre or patently untrue)
 DISORDERS OF PERCEPTIONS

  • Illusion: Misinterpretation of real external stimuli.

  • Hallucination: False sensory perception, externally.

  • Pseudohallucination: False sensory perception from within and having an insight.

  • Depersonalization: Feeling as if one is disconnected from reality, feeling detached from one's own thoughts and one's own physical body.

    "I sometimes drift into a dream-like state where I lose contact with my own self"

  • Derealization: Alteration in the perception or experience of the external world so that it seems unreal.

    "The world and everything around is nothing but just a dream"

Related Pearl: Specific phobia

Clinical features:

  • Marked anxiety about a specific object or situation (the phobic stimulus) for > 6 months
  • Usually develops in childhood, can develop after a traumatic event
  • Avoidance behavior

Treatment:

  • Behavioral therapy (exposure-based, systematic desensitization) is the treatment of choice
  • Short-acting benzodiazepines may help acutely

questions.text:
A young boy who is anticipating his board exams has been increasingly isolated with flat affect for the past 6 months. He has disorganized speech and says he hears a voice telling him that the government is tracking him. On mental status examination, you find that he is depressed. Considering the likely diagnosis, which of the following can be considered a good prognostic factor for him?
  1. Presence of depression
  2. Male sex
  3. Presence of a stressor
  4. Young age of onset
  5. Presence of negative symptoms
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario showing a flat affect, auditory hallucinations, and disorganized speech is highly suggestive of schizophrenia. The presence of a stressor and depression are good prognostic factors.

Schizophrenia is a psychosis, a type of mental illness characterized by distortions in thinking, perception, emotions, language, sense of self, and behavior.

The DSM-5 criteria to diagnose schizophrenia require a total duration of 6 months. Within this 6-month period, there must be at least 1 month of active-phase symptoms (overt psychotic symptoms) where 2 or more of the following have to be present, with at least one among the symptoms a, b, or c: 

  1. Delusion
  2. Hallucination
  3. Disorganized speech (or formal thought disorder)
  4. Disorganized behavior
  5. Affective flattening or other negative symptoms

Studies have pointed out that more than half of the patients generally have a poor prognosis. Poor prognostic factors are associated with repeated hospitalizations, exacerbation of symptoms, and suicide attempts. At least one-third of people with schizophrenia experiences complete remission of symptoms. Some people with schizophrenia experience worsening and remission of symptoms periodically throughout their lives, others a gradual worsening of symptoms over time.

The good and the poor prognostic factors are given below:

Based on the predominant clinical presentation, schizophrenia is divided into five subtypes: paranoid, disorganized, undifferentiated, catatonic, and residual. Antipsychotics form the mainstay of treatment, while psychotherapy is used as an adjunct.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male patient attends your clinic for health check-up. He says that he does not have any friends and does not like to go out often. He lives by himself. Throughout the examination, he does not make eye-contact. He seems quiet for the most part and answers your questions with a single word or phrase. What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
This clinical vignette is strongly suggestive of schizoid personality disorder.

It is a cluster A personality disorder that includes-

  • Paranoid personality disorder
  • Schizoid personality disorder
  • Schizotypal personality disorder.

Schizoid personality disorder is characterized by a tendency for social withdrawal, isolation, and introversion. They tend to live alone and take up jobs that require minimal interpersonal interaction. They are emotionally detached, aloof, and have a flattened affect. They avoid eye contact and conversations and when questioned, are likely to give short direct responses. They do not desire relationships or sexual intimacy and tend not to have partners or friends. However, they have a good attachment with animals. They also tend to have solitary hobbies and interests. 

Other options-

Option A- Paranoid personality disorder is characterized by pervasive suspiciousness and mistrust in all interpersonal relationships. They are excessively fearful about perceived threats and deceit. They tend to be extremely jealous and hostile, argumentative, and defensive. A commonly seen defense mechanism is projection. 

Option B- Avoidant personality disorder is characterized by isolation but a strong wish to participate in activities and relationships. This is absent in those with schizoid personality disor­der where people do not desire social interaction and relationships. 

Option C- Schizotypal personality disorder is characterized by odd perceptions, thinking, and behavior. They tend to have magical thinking, bizarre fantasies, and preoccupations, such as excessive superstition, and beliefs that they have superpowers, etc. They have peculiar speech and an eccentric appearance. They can be differentiated from schizophrenia by the lack of psychotic features.

questions.text: As a part of evaluation, a psychiatrist enumerates all the colors of the rainbow to his patient. The next day, when the patient was asked to recollect these colors, he was unable to recollect the 6th color. The doctor mentioned the first few letters of the color, and then the patient answered. The function of which part of the brain is evaluated here?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, priming is being assessed, which depends on the functioning of the neocortex.

Priming is a form of nondeclarative memory that helps in recognizing words or objects to which the person was exposed previously. It is usually assessed by checking for increased reading speed, faster naming of objects, and faster recollection of getting a clue when presented with previously exposed information.

Memory is usually divided into two forms:

  • Explicit or declarative memory is associated with consciousness or awareness.
  • Implicit or non-declarative memory does not involve awareness and its retention. It does not involve the hippocampus in its processing.

Memory can also be classified as:

Short-term memory- lasts for a few seconds to minutes. Working memory is a form of short-term memory. It keeps the information available, usually for a very short time, until the individual plans some action based on it.

Long-term memory can be recollected after years or even for a lifetime. These memories are stored in various parts of the neocortex. The various types of the memories such as visual, auditory, olfactory, etc., are localized to the cortical regions.

Other options:

Option 1: Striatum forms a part of the basal ganglia and is involved in decision-making functions, such as motor control, emotion, habit formation, and reward.

Option 2: Amygdala, a component of the limbic system, is responsible for the control of emotions, behavior, and memory formation. 

Option 3: Cerebellum is responsible for the coordination of movement, maintaining posture and balance, muscle tone, and motor learning.

Related Pearl: Forms of Memory

From physiologic point of view memory is divided into explicit and implicit forms.

Related Pearl: Tests for evaluating attention, concentration and memory

Memory:

Memory is of 3 types:

  • Immediate memory and recall are usually tested by digit span/ digit repetition test.
    • Digit span test: Digits spelled at the rate of 1 digit per second. It is of two types: Digit forward and Digit backward.
    • Digit forward: Reproduction of increasingly longer digits. E.g., Examiner says 2 - 4 –8 –1 –5 –7 - 9. The person has to repeat in the same order 2 – 4 – 8 –1 –5 –7 –9.
    • Digit backward: Reproduction of longer digits in the backward direction. Eg: Examiner says 2 - 4 –8 –1 –5 –7 - 9. The person has to repeat it backward. 9 -7 -5 -1 -8- 4- 2.
    • The above tests should be stopped when there are 2 successive failures. Hence 2 skips are not allowed.
  • Recent memory: Ask them how they reached the hospital or what they ate for breakfast.
  • Remote memory: Relevant questions from the past like close relative's birth dates. 

Attention:

  • Is the patient's attention easily aroused and sustained?
  • Digit span test.

Concentration:

  • Is the patient easily distractable or can they concentrate?
  • Serial subtraction test: Minimum of five subtractions done serially is taken into account
  • Count backward from 20.
  • Enumerate the months in reverse order.

questions.text: You are a psychiatry junior resident who is called to the medicine ward to assess a 68-year-old woman for suspected signs of delirium. You proceed to evaluate for delirium using the confusion assessment method. The presence of which of the following is not required for the diagnosis of delirium in this method?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario of a patient suspected of delirium, the confusion assessment method (CAM) diagnostic algorithm can be used as a screening tool. The presence of signs of psychomotor activity is not required for the diagnosis of delirium in this method.

The Confusion Assessment Method (CAM) is used as a screening tool and the diagnosis of delirium requires the presence of:

  • Acute onset and fluctuating course (Options A & D), 
  • Inattention (Option C), and
  • either disorganized thinking or an altered level of consciousness

Other screening tools that can aid in identifying patients with delirium are:

  • Nursing Delirium Screening Scale (NuDESC)
  • Organic Brain Syndrome Scale
  • Delirium Rating Scale
  • ICU version of the CAM
  • Delirium Detection Score

Delirium, a life-threatening but reversible CNS disorder, is characterized by an acute decline in the level of consciousness and global impairment of cognitive functions. It has an acute onset (hours to days) and prodromal symptoms like restlessness and fearfulness can be seen. with a fluctuating course. The episodes are usually brief lasting from days to weeks and follow a fluctuating course.

The hallmark feature is a decline in the level of consciousness, particularly altered attention. It is accompanied by impairment in cognitive function manifesting as disorientation and decreased memory. Abnormalities of mood, perceptual disturbances like illusions and hallucinations, and behavioral abnormalities are common psychiatric manifestations. 

Abnormal psychomotor activity is also seen, although it is not used during assessment via the Confusion Assessment Method (CAM). Other clinical features include sleep cycle impairment, worsening of symptoms at night (sundowning), and neurological manifestations like autonomic instability.

The major neuroanatomical area and the major neurotransmitter hypothesized are the reticular formation and acetylcholine, respectively. The precipitating factors include drugs like sedatives-hypnotics and narcotics, neurological diseases like meningitis and stroke, intercurrent illnesses like infections and hypoxia, environmental stressors, and major surgeries.

Delirium is a clinical diagnosis and screening tools like CAM are used for it. The primary goal of treatment is to identify the underlying cause and rapid improvement can be seen once it is eliminated. Management requires prompt supportive care. Antipsychotics like haloperidol, for managing psychotic symptoms, and short-acting benzodiazepines like lorazepam, for managing insomnia, may be required. Delirium is associated with high morbidity, and thus, the predisposing and precipitating factors should be identified to prevent an episode of delirium.

questions.text: Which among the following is not an indication for the use of electroconvulsive therapy (ECT)?
questions.solution:
Indications of ECT:

Diagnostic indications - 

  • Major depression (Bipolar and unipolar)
  • Psychotic depression (Option A)
  • Mania
  • Acute exacerbation of schizophrenia
  • Catatonic schizophrenia
  • Schizoaffective disorder (Option D)
  • Parkinson's disease (Option C)
  • Neuroleptic malignant disorder

Panic disorder is not an indication of the use of electroconvulsive therapy. 

Clinical indications - 

  • Primary - 
    • When rapid response is required
    • When the risk of other treatment modalities outweighs the benefits
    • Poor response to previous antipsychotic therapy
    • Good response to previous ECT therapy
    • Preference of patient
  • Secondary - 
    • Poor response or failure to respond to pharmacotherapy in the current episode
    • Rapid definitive response necessitated by the deterioration of the patient's condition

Electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) is not effective in somatization disorder (unless accompanied by depression), personality disorders, and anxiety disorders such as panic disorder.

questions.text: A middle-aged chronic smoker has recently been discharged from the hospital after being admitted for an acute exacerbation of chronic bronchitis. He is now motivated to quit smoking and wants to know about medications that will help him with quitting. All of the following can be used in him, except ______.
questions.solution:
Mirtazapine is not used in smoking cessation.

Mirtazapine is a serotonin receptor antagonist, used in the treatment of major depression.

Pharmacological methods to quit smoking:

1. Nicotine replacement therapy - is highly effective, because it reduces withdrawal symptoms. It is available as - 

  • Nicotine gum - available over the counter and releases nicotine via buccal absorption. One to two pieces of gum per hour up to a maximum of 24 pieces per day can be used
  • Nicotine lozenges - useful for patients who smoke a cigarette immediately on awakening
  • Nicotine patches - administered every morning and produce blood concentrations of nicotine about half those of smoking
  • Nicotine nasal spray - available only by prescription, produces nicotine concentrations in the blood comparable to smoking a cigarette and is helpful for heavily dependent smokers However, adverse effects like rhinitis, watering eyes, and coughing are experienced by most patients
  • Nicotine inhalers deliver 4 mg per cartridge and resultant nicotine levels are low

2. Non-nicotine medications:

1st line:

  • Bupropion - both dopaminergic and adrenergic actions. 
  • Varenicline - a partial agonist for nicotinic Ach receptor. Side effects include sleep disturbances, depression, and increased suicidal tendencies.

2nd line:

  • Nortriptyline - tricyclic antidepressant which appears to be effective for smoking cessation.
  • Clonidine - alpha-agonist which decreases sympathetic activity and thus decreases withdrawal symptoms.

It is recommended to offer nicotine patches or varenicline along with counselling and behavior therapy as a part of the cessation attempt. Acute exacerbations of chronic bronchitis are valuable "teachable moments" for the patient and can help reaffirm the smoking cessation message serving as a springboard for a cessation attempt.

questions.text: In a patient with insomnia, agitation, and restlessness, the presence of which of the following symptoms differentiates a manic episode from a hypomanic episode?
questions.solution:
The presence of psychotic features, such as hallucinations, differentiates an episode of hypomania from mania.

The diagnostic criteria for mania as given by DSM-V is:

A. Distinct period of abnormally and persistently elevated/irritable mood, abnormally and persistently increased activity/energy, lasting at least 1 week.

B. During the period of mood disturbance and increased energy/activity, three (or more) of the following symptoms are present to a significant degree:

  • Increased self-esteem or grandiosity
  • Decreased need for sleep
  • More talkative than usual or a pressure to keep talking
  • Flight of ideas
  • Distractibility
  • Increase in goal-directed activity or psychomotor agitation (purposeless non-goal-directed activity)
  • Excessive involvement in activities that have a high potential for painful consequences 

These symptoms should either cause marked social distress with a need for hospitalization or psychotic features must be present. These symptoms should not be attributable to other organic disorders or substance abuse.

Hypomania is a distinct period of abnormally and persistently elevated/irritable mood, abnormally and persistently increased activity/energy, lasting for at least 4 days. It is similar to a manic episode wherein the patients can portray all of the above-mentioned symptoms but it is not severe enough to cause impairment in social or occupational functioning. No psychotic features are present. In the presence of psychotic features, the episode, by definition, becomes one of mania.

 

Related Pearl: Bipolar disorder

Bipolar & related disorders

Manic episode

  • Symptoms more severe
  • 1 week unless hospitalized
  • Marked impairment in social or occupational functioning or hospitalization necessary
  • May have psychotic features; makes episode manic by definition

Hypomanic episode  

  • Symptoms less severe
  • 4 days to less than 7 days
  • Unequivocal, observable change in functioning from patient's baseline
  • Symptoms not severe enough to cause marked impairment or necessitate hospitalization
  • No psychotic features

Bipolar I

  • Manic episode(s)
  • Depressive episodes common (but not required for diagnosis)

Bipolar II

  • Hypomanic episode(s)
  • Major depressive episodes (required for diagnosis)

Cyclothymic disorder

  • At least 2 years of fluctuating, mild hypomanic & depressive symptoms that
    do not meet criteria for hypomanic episodes or major depressive episodes

Related Pearl: Treatment of acute manic episode

There is no single drug of choice for the treatment of acute mania. 

If the patient is on anti-depressants: Stop antidepressants. 

If the patient is already on anti-manic medication: 

  • If already on lithium or valproate: increase the dose of lithium or valproate and consider adding an antipsychotic. 
  • Consider adding short-term benzodiazepines for all patients. 

If the patient is not on anti-manic medication:

  • Consider an antipsychotic if symptoms are severe and behavior is disturbed (or)
  • Consider valproate, but avoid in women of reproductive age (or)
  • Consider lithium if future adherence is likely 
  • Consider adding short-term benzodiazepines for all patients.

questions.text:
Which of the following disorders falls under the obsessive-compulsive spectrum of disorders according to DSM-V?
  1. Skin picking disorder
  2. Factitious disorder
  3. Body dysmorphic disorder
  4. Trichotillomania
  5. Oppositional defiant disorder
questions.solution:
Among the given options skin picking disorder, body dysmorphic disorder, and trichotillomania fall under obsessive-compulsive and related disorders according to DSM-V.

Obsessive-compulsive and related disorders:

It refers to a group of disorders that are characterized by repetitive thoughts and behaviors that share similar etiologies and important diagnostic validators. Important features of these disorders are obsessions, intrusive thoughts, and preoccupations. It includes:

  • Obsessive-compulsive disorder - It is characterized by repetitive and intrusive thoughts that are unwelcome (obsessions) or repetitive behaviors that the person feels compelled to do (compulsions) or both.
  • Body dysmorphic disorder - This is characterized by marked distress about an imagined or slight defect in appearance which keeps the patient preoccupied.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man who has been diagnosed with intellectual disability lives in a group home. He can perform his morning routine of brushing, bathing, and dressing up with adequate help. He can also perform simple tasks under supervision. What level of intellectual disability is portrayed by this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario showing a 24 year old male living in a group home under supervision with the ability to perform small work-related skills is indicative of severe intellectual disability.

According to DSM-5, the classification of the level of intellectual disability (ID) is assessed by deficits in adaptive functioning (not IQ scores).

The diagnostic criteria of ID include:

  • Significant deficits in intellectual functioning (reasoning, learning, and problem-solving)
  • Significant deficits in adaptive behavior (conceptual, social, and practical skills)
  • Age at onset in the developmental period

It is to be noted that in DSM-5, adaptive behavior is considered more significant than calculated IQ level in determining the severity of intellectual disability. DSM-4 diagnostic criteria and severity classification for intellectual disability was primarily based on the IQ level.

    • Can study till 6th grade
    • They are successful and independent
    • Have an IQ range of 50-70
    • They can do unskilled and semi-skilled work without supervision
  • Moderate intellectual disability
    • Trainable
    • Can study up to second to third grade.
    • Have an IQ range of 35 - 50
    • They can do unskilled and semiskilled work under supervision
  • Severe intellectual disability
    • They develop communication skills in childhood and can learn to count and recognize important words.
    • Cannot be educated
    • Have an IQ range of 20 - 35
    • They can do simple tasks under supervision
  • Profound intellectual disability
    • Require continuous supervision and care
    • Have an IQ below 20

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman was diagnosed with bipolar disorder and has been taking lithium for the past 5 years. She is currently in remission. However, she now presented to the OPD with worsening depression, fatigue, weight loss, abdominal pain, renal colic, and bone pain. Which of the following tests would most likely reveal the underlying cause of her symptoms?
questions.solution:
The clinical features are suggestive of hypercalcemia due to prolonged lithium therapy. Serum calcium levels should be assessed.

Lithium is used in the treatment of bipolar disorders in combination with other drugs such as antidepressants, antipsychotics, and benzodiazepines. One of the common adverse effects of prolonged lithium therapy is hyperparathyroidism, which presents with signs and symptoms of hypercalcemia.

Patients with hypercalcemia, depending on the severity, may present with symptoms, which include: fatigue, lethargy, anorexia, nausea, abdominal pain, constipation, bone pain, depression, polyuria, polydipsia, and renal colic. The classic symptoms of hyperparathyroidism are described as 'bones, stones, and abdominal groans'.

The adverse effects of lithium include:

  • Neurological:
    • memory difficulties, tremors, peripheral neuropathy
    • dysarthria, ataxia, seizures
    • benign intracranial hypertension, myasthenia gravis-like syndrome
  • Endocrine: goiter, hypothyroidism, hyperthyroidism (rare), hyperparathyroidism
  • Cardiovascular: benign T-wave changes, sinus node dysfunction
  • Renal: nephrogenic diabetes insipidus, renal tubular acidosis
  • Dermatological: Acne, hair loss, psoriasis
  • Gastrointestinal: Appetite loss, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea 

Other options:

  • Serum ferritin levels are not known to be affected with lithium therapy.
  • Some studies have shown that vitamin B12 levels may be reduced with lithium therapy. However, the symptoms given in the question are mostly related to hypercalcemia.
  • Patients with bipolar disorder on lithium therapy, are more likely to develop hypothyroidism. Thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH) levels may be monitored in these patients. However, as per the given clinical scenario, a patient with hypothyroidism is unlikely to have weight loss and bone pain. Hence serum calcium is the preferred option.

questions.text: A female patient presents to you with the complaint that she needs to check if the front door of her home is locked at least 10-15 times a day, which leads to poor performance at work. She understands that this habit is irrational but she feels extremely anxious due to repetitive thoughts that her door is unlocked but has not been treated for the condition before.  which of these management options would you suggest for this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette is suggestive of a diagnosis of obsessive-compulsive disorder which can be managed by behavior therapy.

Obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) comprises symptoms that include intrusive thoughts, ritu­als, preoccupations, and compulsions, which cause severe distress to the patient.

Behavior therapy and pharmacotherapy can be used alone or in combination for the management of this condition. Behavior therapy is thought to be longer-lasting than pharmacotherapy. Hence, it is considered the treatment of choice by many clinicians. Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors or clomipramine are used for medical management.

The recurrent and intrusive thoughts, feelings, ideas, and sensations are referred to as obsessions. Conscious, standardized, recurrent behaviors are called compulsions, such as counting and checking, and are done to reduce the anxiety associated with the obsession. The patient might have an obsession, a compulsion, or both.

It is associated with other mental disorders such as major depressive disorder, generalized anxiety disorder, and specific phobias. In adults, it is seen with equal prevalence among men and women. The four major symptom patterns include contamination, pathological doubt, intrusive thoughts, and symmetry.

Other options:

Option A: Cingulotomy is carried out in severe and treatment-unresponsive patients.

Option B: Electroconvulsive therapy can be considered in treatment-resistant and chronically debilitating conditions.

Option D: Antipsychotics such as risperidone have been helpful in some cases when added to the treatment.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman complains of excessive daytime sleepiness and sudden bouts of sleep. The symptoms began at the age of 11 and have been worsening. She couldn’t stay awake during her classes or exams and often dozed off standing up, while working. Eventually, she developed episodes of sudden loss of muscle tone, precipitated by strong emotions. What is most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of narcolepsy.

It is characterized by the tetrad of: 

  1. Excessive daytime sleepiness
  2. Cataplexy (sudden loss of muscle tone)
  3. Hypnagogic/hypnopompic hallucinations
  4. Sleep paralysis

The hallmark of narcolepsy is decreased REM latency, i.e. decreased latent period before the first REM period occurs. Normal REM latency is 90-100 minutes. In narcolepsy, REM-sleep usually occurs within 10 minutes of the onset of sleep (sleep onset REM).

Treatment: 

  • Sleep hygiene
  • Scheduled naps
  • Avoidance of alcohol and drugs that cause drowsiness
  • Drugs: 
    • Modafinil (wakefulness-promoting drug) is the drug of choice.
    • Amphetamines
    • Methylphenidate

questions.text: A male patient who lost his job recently became irritable and had a sad mood for most of the time. Thinking about the future worried him and he felt irritation towards his family members. He occasionally went out to watch movies with his friends and was able to enjoy but on returning home he felt similar symptoms. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical features are suggestive of an adjustment disorder.

Adjustment disorder is an emotional response to a stressful event. Stressors may be single like loss of job or divorce; multiple like the death of a parent together with loss of a job; or recurrent like seasonal business difficulties.

Diagnosing criteria for adjustment disorder:

  • Development of emotional or behavioural response within 3 months of the onset of the stressor.
  • The symptoms or behaviour are clinically significant, where, any one of the following are met:
    • The response is out of proportion to the severity or intensity of the stressor.
    • Significant impairment in social, occupational, or other areas of functioning.
  • The stress-related disturbance does not meet the criteria for another mental disorder or exacerbation of pre-existing mental disorder.
  • Mostly depressive but can also have anxiety symptoms.
  • The symptoms disappear within 6 months if the stressor is removed.

In the given case, it has been mentioned that the patient lost his job recently. Although a time period is not mentioned in the question, the term recently can be understood as well within the 3 months duration. The patient's behaviour such as sad and irritated affected his social functioning. As he was finding joy in watching movies, depression can be ruled out.

questions.text: A 26-year-old girl who is a victim of rape by her uncle is brought to the psychiatric department by her father. She cannot recall any details about the assault. She remembers events that led up to the assault and the events that followed, but when asked general questions about her uncle, she does not know who he is. She does not recall childhood memories involving her uncle either. What is the most likely diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
The patient has features of dissociative amnesia. This patient's inability to remember a specific category of information, in this case, about one particular person is indicative of systematized amnesia.

Dissociative amnesia is defined as an inability to recall important auto­biographical information that is successfully stored in memory and ordinar­ily would be readily remembered. It is potentially reversible (unlike amnesias due to neuro-biological damage). The amnesia is predominantly retrograde with minimal anterograde amnesia. It usually follows severe emotional trauma, interpersonal conflicts, and other stressful events, such as sexual abuse, loss of a loved one, or loss of livelihood.

Diagnostic features: 

  • The amnesia is usually associated with an event that is traumatic or stressful in nature that causes considerable distress in the patient's day-to-day activities.
  • It should not be attributable to substance abuse or organic conditions.

It is further categorized into the following types:

  • Selective amnesia - ability to remember some, but not all, of the events occurring during a circumscribed period of time. (Option D)
  • Localized amnesia - inability to recall all events related to a circumscribed period of time. (Option B)
  • Generalized amnesia - failure to recall one’s entire life.
  • Continuous amnesia - failure to recall successive events as they occur. (Option A)
  • Systematized amnesia - amnesia for certain categories of memory, such as all memories relating to one’s family or a particular person.

questions.text: A patient who was diagnosed with hyperthyroidism undergoes a total thyroidectomy.  A few days after surgery she experiences parasthesia of the fingers and toes  Laboratory investigations values showed hypoparathyroidism. questions.solution:
The most common psychiatric manifestation of hypoparathyroidism is delirium. 

Delirium is a sudden state of impaired consciousness and cognitive function which is usually reversible. Acetylcholine is the neurotransmitter involved. Symptoms worsening at night (sundowning) along with illusions and hallucinations are also seen. It is detected using the confusion assessment test. 

Hypoparathyroidism is characterized by low serum PTH levels and occurs as a result of thyroid or parathyroid surgeries. This results in hypocalcemia and the clinical features are paraesthesia of the fingers and toes, carpopedal spasm, bronchospasm, and prolongation of the QT interval etc. 

On examination, two signs are seen:

  • Chvostek's sign: Twitching of the circumoral muscles when the facial nerve is tapped anterior to the ear
  • Trousseau’s sign: Carpal spasm induced by inflation of BP cuff.

questions.text: You notice a patient lying in the hospital compound with his attendant, to be seen by a psychiatrist. He does not react when you lend him a hand to make him stand. He doesn't move or respond to any other instruction given by the attendant. This behavior can be best described as:
questions.solution:
The behavior of not responding to instructions and external stimuli is known as negativism.

Negativism is a feature seen in catatonia. Verbal or nonverbal opposition to suggestions or advice is exhibited. There is resistance to efforts to be moved and the patient might even do the opposite of what is asked.

Catatonia is a condition seen in advanced primary mood or psychotic illnesses. It is a new diagnostic category in the diagnostic and statistical manual of mental disorders, fifth edition (DSM-5). A diagnosis of catatonia is not made if there is a primary mental disorder such as schizophrenia or psychotic depression, or if present during the course of delirium. 

Abnormal behaviors include grimacing, mutism, echolalia, stupor, and posturing. Wavy flexibility is marked by uniform resistance offered to passive positioning. Catalepsy is a passively inducted posture that is maintained against gravity by the patient. 

Some conditions that can cause catatonia include head trauma, encephalitis, and hepatic encephalopathy. Some medications such as corticosteroids, immunosuppressants, or antipsychotics can also result in the condition. It can also be seen in neuroleptic-induced parkinsonism and neuroleptic malignant syndrome.

The primary treatment for catatonia includes identifying and treating underlying medical or pharmacological causes. Any offending substances should be removed. Benzodiazepines are effective in reducing the symptoms of catatonia temporarily. Electroconvulsive therapy should be started for catatonia that is not responding to benzodiazepines and in severe cases with life-threatening conditions such as refusal to eat. 

Other options:

Option A: Mannerisms are normal movements that look odd and are involuntary. 

Option B: Stereotypy is purposeless repetitive speech or movements.

Option D: Echopraxia is characterized by mimicking an observed movement.

Related Pearl: Key points on electroconvulsive therapy

Produces grand mal seizure in an anesthetized patient.

Mechanism of action:

  • Neuroplasticity: Ability of the brain to form and reorganize synaptic connections.
  • Increases levels of Brain-Derived Growth Factor and Vascular Endothelial Growth Factor

Indications:

  • Treatment-resistant depression
  • Severe depression with suicidal risk (most common indication)
  • Depression with psychotic features
  • Depressed suicidal pregnant women
  • Refusal to eat or drink
  • Imminent risk for suicide
  • Neuroleptic malignant syndrome
  • Catatonia and catatonic schizophrenia
  • Severe agitated depression

Electrode placement: Bifrontotemporal, right unilateral.

Anesthetic agent: Methohexital (most common)

Adverse effects:

  • Retrograde amnesia (most common)
  • Partial anterograde amnesia
  • Disorientation
  • Temporary headache

Memory disturbances recover within 1-6 months. Safe in pregnancy. ECT can reverse extrapyramidal symptoms of neuroleptics.

Contraindications: No absolute contraindication (raised intracranial tension is considered as a relative contraindication).

Increased risk of adverse effects in:

  • Severe cardiovascular disease, recent myocardial infarction
  • Space occupying brain lesion
  • Recent stroke, unstable aneurysm

Related Pearl: Pharmacological treatment of psychosis

First-generation antipsychotics are generally not preferred due to the higher risk of extrapyramidal side effects/ tardive dyskinesia.

Second-generation antipsychotics are preferred drugs:

  • Risperidone
  • Olanzapine
  • Quetiapine
  • Aripiprazole
  • Ziprasidone
  • Paliperidone

Benzodiazepines can be added to treat associated agitation. It is the drug of choice for catatonia.

  • Emergency: Use a short-acting intramuscular agent such as haloperidol, fluphenazine, olanzapine, or ziprasidone.
  • Chronic compliance: Long-acting injectable is used.
  • Treatment resistance (2 failed trials): Consider Clozapine.
  • All meds ineffective: May consider ECT.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient diagnosed with treatment-resistant schizophrenia has been started on clozapine. Which of the following is the most serious side effect of this medication?
questions.solution:
The most serious side effect of clozapine is agranulocytosis. 

Clozapine is an atypical anti-psychotic drug that acts via D4 receptors and 5­HT2 as well as α adrenergic block. It is only used in treatment-resistant schizophrenia. 

Other side effects of clozapine include diabetes, weight gain, sedation, hypersalivation, fever, tachycardia, and postural hypotension. Seizures are more common with clozapine than with other antipsychotic drugs. 

Other options:

Option A - Corneal & lenticular deposits are seen with chlorpromazine which is a typical antipsychotic. 

Option B - Prolongation of QT is seen with ziprasidone which is an atypical antipsychotic. 

Option C - Extrapyramidal side effects are less common with clozapine, but more frequently seen with typical antipsychotics. They are acute dystonia, tardive dyskinesia, akathisia, neuroleptic malignant syndrome etc.

questions.text: A woman who was a victim of sexual assault finally opens up to her group during group therapy about the night of the assault and reveals suppressed memories. After doing so, she feels a sense of relief. Which of the following best describes what this woman experienced?
questions.solution:
The sense of relief that the woman experiences on expressing her suppressed memories is known as catharsis.

Catharsis is a general term for the process of releasing strong or suppressed emotions. The expression of ideas, thoughts, and suppressed emotions is accompanied by an emotional response that produces a state of relief in the patient. 

Other options:

Transference is a psychoanalytical term for the projection of feelings, thoughts, and wishes by the patient onto the therapist. It occurs when the patients transfer their feelings towards an object from their past onto the therapist. This reaction is considered inappropriate in present-day clinical setting.

Altruism is a beneficial factor of group therapy wherein a member of the group helps another member by putting that person's need before their own By doing so, the person learns the value of giving to others. 

Insight is when a patient gains awareness and understanding of their own psychodynamics and symptoms of maladaptive behavior.

These are mainly of two types:

  • Intellectual insight - This refers to knowledge and awareness of the person but does not reflect any changes in the maladaptive behavior
  • Emotional insight - This is awareness and understanding which leads to a positive change in the personality and behavior of that person.

questions.text: The parents of a 6-year-old child were informed that he does not speak at all in school but performs well academically. His parents are surprised as he communicates normally at home with no abnormal behavior. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis based on the clinical scenario described is selective mutism. 

Selective mutism refers to the persistent lack of speaking in one or more specific social situations. The child is able to speak well in other situations, like at home. 

The disorder may develop in children between 4 to 8 years of age and is associated with a social anxiety disorder. They may have symptoms of separation anxi­ety disorder, school refusal, and delayed language acquisition. The child may be either completely silent at school or maybe just whispering. Rarely, a child may be silent at home but communicate normally at school.

Maternal overprotection and anxiety disorders in parents may exacerbate the condition. Some children may develop selective mutism after emotional or physical trauma.

Selectively mute children may have an increased risk for delayed speech and language acquisition and disturbances in auditory processing. They may also exhibit behavioral disturbances, like temper tan­trums and oppositional behavior at home.

Treatment includes a combination of psychoeducation for the family, cognitive behavioral therapy, and selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors if needed. Pre-school children seem to have a positive response to a therapeutic nursery.

Other options:

Option A: Expressive language deficits refer to a shortfall in expressive language development with normal nonverbal intellectual function. It is frequently seen in autism spectrum disorders. It is marked by limited vocabulary and variable articulation.

Option B: In severe intellectual disability children can present with minimal speech during preschool years along with impaired motor development. Some language development might occur later on.

Option D: Rett syndrome is a progressive autism spectrum disorder predominantly seen in girls. The onset is after a few months of apparently normal development. Marked regression of all language skills and plateaued communicative and social skills are seen.

questions.text: A young woman presents with complaints of severe insomnia. She has been feeling ants walking over the skin of her legs, and an irresistible urge to move the legs when at rest or while trying to fall asleep. The drug of choice for treating this condition would be:
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette of a patient with insomnia feeling ants walking over her skin along with an irresistible urge to move her legs when at rest or while trying to fall asleep is indicative of restless leg syndrome and gabapentin is the first-line choice of treatment for this condition.    

Restless leg syndrome is a typical sensory-motor disorder that generally affects the legs during rest periods, especially sleep. There is an irresistible urge to shake the legs associated with a burning sensation, itching, and cramps of the legs. Moving the leg or walking alleviates the symptoms. This cycle sometimes continues for hours during the night and can result in profound insomnia. Decreased dopamine receptor expression and mild dopaminergic hypofunction are usually noted in these patients.

In patients with restless legs syndrome, iron stores are initially repleted, and the aggravating factors are eliminated. If RLS still persists, initial therapy with a gabapentinoid (pregabalin, gabapentin, gabapentin enacarbil) is preferred, rather than a dopamine agonist (pramipexole, ropinirole, rotigotine). This is due to the high frequency of intermediate and long-term augmentation with dopamine agonists, as well as their risk of impulse control disorders.

FDA-approved drugs for the treatment of restless leg syndrome: 

  • Gabapentin
  • Ropinirole
  • Pramipexole
  • Rotigotine 

A dopamine agonist is used as an alternative in patients with increased risk for side effects from gabapentinoids, such as those with obesity and its complications, a past or present history of moderate to severe depression, a disorder causing gait instability or respiratory failure, and a history of substance use disorder.

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic man wanted to overcome his alcohol addiction and abstained from alcohol for 3 days. On the third day, he developed tremors and hallucinations. He was brought to the emergency and was found to be disoriented. His heart rate and blood pressure were increased. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis based on the clinical features is delirium tremens.

Delirium tremens is the most severe form of alcohol withdrawal syndrome. The patients present with confusion, agitation, and fluctuating levels of consciousness. Visual or tactile hallucinations along with features of autonomic hyperactivity like tremors, tachycardia, diaphoresis, fever, insomnia, and increased blood pressure are also seen. 

It usually occurs within 72 hours of abstinence, however, may occur within a week of alcohol withdrawal. Acute infection, hepatitis, and pancreatitis predispose delirium tremens.

Delirium tremens is treated with benzodiazepines such as chlordiazepoxide. It is also recommended to administer thiamine in patients with alcohol-related disorders to prevent Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome.

Other options:

Option A: Alcohol withdrawal-related hallucinations- These are usually auditory hallucinations occurring during alcohol withdrawal. In this condition, the patient has a clear sensorium, which differentiates it from delirium tremens.

Option B: Korsakoff's psychosis is an amnestic syndrome that occurs due to thiamine deficiency. The clinical features include impairment of memory, confabulations, and disordered temporal sequencing. Thiamine supplementation and nutritional support are given to these patients. However, the patients show only a little improvement because of irreversible damage to the medial thalamic nuclei and mammillary bodies caused by thiamine deficiency.

Option D: Marchiafava-Bignami disease is a syndrome characterized by dementia and seizures, associated with degeneration of the corpus callosum. It has been observed in male Italian red wine drinkers.

questions.text: A male patient complains of fatigue, low self-esteem, feeling hopeless, and not being able to concentrate on work. A diagnosis of dysthymia is made. What is the minimum duration of the symptoms to arrive at this diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The minimum duration that the symptoms should persist in order to make a diagnosis of dysthymia /persistent depressive disorder is two years. 

Dysthymia refers to a persistent depressive mood lasting for more than two years in adults (1 year in children and adolescents). It is not severe enough to be diagnosed as major depression and has an insidious onset. The low mood persists for most of the day. It is accompanied by low self-esteem, insomnia or hypersomnia, fatigue, poor appetite,  poor concentration, and hopelessness.

The onset can be either early (before the age of 21) which is more common or late. It affects both genders equally. It is frequently associated with depression, anxiety disorders, substance abuse, and borderline personality disorder.

The two important differential diagnoses are minor depressive disorder and recurrent brief depressive disorder. In the former, patients have episodic symptoms and euthymic moods in between. In the latter, the episodic nature of more severe symptoms is seen.

The most effective treatment involves a combination of psychotherapy and pharmacotherapy. Insight-oriented psychotherapy, cognitive therapy, and behavioral therapy are used. Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) like escitalopram and sertraline are effective.

Hospitalization is usually not indicated in dysthymia. However, severe symptoms, marked impairment in social or occupational functioning, and suicidal ideation require hospitalization.

questions.text: In the experiment shown below, what role does the whistle play?
questions.solution:
The experiment shown in the image is that of classical conditioning by Ivan Pavlov. The whistle plays the role of a conditional stimulus.

Classical conditioning is the theory of learning where neutral stimuli are associated with psychologically significant events.

Events in the Pavlov experiment:

  • Food - Unconditional stimulus (Option B) as it elicits salivation before the experiment commences
  • Response to food - Salivation as a result of the unconditional stimulus is the unconditional response (Option A) as it is elicited before the commencement of the experiment.
  • Bell/Whistle - Conditional stimulus as it elicits salivation conditional to the pairing of the bell and food
  • Response to the bell/whistle - This is known as the conditional response (Option C) as the dog has been conditioned to react to the conditional stimulus.

This model usually deals with involuntary responses. It is also called learning by association or respondent conditioning. He's also known for his work on the physiology of digestion

questions.text: A psychiatrist is conducting the Folstein test as a part of the psychiatric evaluation of a patient. Which of the following is being evaluated?
questions.solution:
The Folstein test also known as the mini-mental state examination (MMSE) is used to test cognitive functioning.

MMSE is a 30-point questionnaire from categories including orientation, attention, memory, construction, and language which tallies up to a score of 30. It is easy to administer and takes less than ten minutes for completion. A score of less than 24 points to cognitive impairment.

It can be used to screen for and assess dementia. Some other screening tools are the Montreal cognitive assessment (MOCA), the tablet-based cognitive assessment tool, and cognistat.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with mood lability, sadness, and tearfulness 5 days after delivery. She has no thoughts of harming the baby. There is no history of previous mood disorders. There is no family history of mood disorders. What is the preferred treatment for her?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features are suggestive of postpartum blues and the preferred treatment is supportive therapy.

Mild depressive symptoms after a few days of delivery which resolve spontaneously are characteristic of postpartum blues.

During this period the patient may experience mood lability, sadness, dysphoria, subjective confusion, and tearfulness. These feelings have been ascribed to rapid changes in women's hormonal levels, the stress of childbirth, and the awareness of the increased responsibility that motherhood brings. This usually resolves spontaneously. 

If the symptoms persist longer than two weeks, evaluation is indicated for postpartum depression.
