questions.text: A 10-year-old boy is brought with complaints of erratic behaviour in school. He is unable to sit still in class for more than a few minutes at a time, pushes other children, never waits for his turn, and disturbs his classmates. His parents say that he is hyperactive at home as well. The language and milestones are appropriate for his age. Any of the following drugs can be used in his condition except:
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario described above of a child with inattention and hyperactivity points towards a diagnosis of attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD). Tricyclic antidepressants like desipramine are not recommended in the treatment of ADHD due to potential cardiac arrhythmia effects. There have been reports of sudden death in children with ADHD being treated with desipramine.

Pharmacotherapy is the first line of treatment for ADHD. CNS stimulants are the first-choice agents as they have shown the greatest efficacy with mild tolerable side effects. The CNS stimulants used are dopamine agonists like methylphenidate, amphetamine salts, and dextroamphetamine. Non-stimulant medications used in the treatment of ADHD include atomoxetine (norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor), clonidine, and guanfacine (Alpha agonists).

Psychosocial interventions such as academic organization skills remediation, parent training, behavior modification in the classroom and at home, cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT), and social skills training are also used as an adjunct to pharmacotherapy.

Attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) is a neuro­ psychiatric condition characterized by a pattern of diminished attention span and increased impulsivity or hyperactivity. The prefrontal cortex of the brain has been implicated in its etiology and dopamine is the main neurotransmitter. 

ADHD can begin during infancy but is usually rec­ognized between 1-3 years of age. ADHD was known as minimal brain dysfunction earlier. The characteristics of children with ADHD, in order of frequency, are

  • Hyperactivity
  • Attention deficit (short attention span, distractibility)
  • Impulsivity (action before thought, abrupt shifts in activity, lack of organization)
  • Memory and thinking deficits
  • Specific learning disabilities
  • Speech and hearing deficits.

Under DSM-5 criteria, for diagnosis of ADHD, it is necessary for symptoms to be present prior to age 12, persist for at least 6 months, have a negative impact on social, academic, or occupational activities, and be present in two or more settings.

The course of ADHD is variable. The majority of the cases persist into adult life. The hyperactivity may disappear in some cases, but the decreased attention span and impulse-control problems usually persist. Patients with ADHD are vulnerable to antisocial behavior, conduct disorder, substance use disorders, and mood disorders.

questions.text: A 48-year-old male patient is brought to the psychiatry OPD by his wife. He is convinced that the lead actress of a film he watched recently is deeply in love with him and wants to marry him. She also says that he is socially withdrawn and doesn't have many friends. Upon conducting a mental status examination, there are no other significant findings. What is the most likely diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the man has a false belief that his chairman wants to marry him, which is a delusion of love, also known as de Clérambault syndrome/erotomania /psychose passionelle.

Delusions are false beliefs that are firmly held despite objective and obvious contradictory proof. It can be present in conditions like schizophrenia, mania, major depressive disorders, and delusional disorders. 

The erotomania is more common in women but can be seen in men as well. The patient feels that someone, who is usually of a higher status, is deeply in love with them. Patients with this delusion are usually solitary, withdrawn, dependent, and sexually inhibited. It is usually sudden in onset and runs a chronic course. It is seen in conditions like schizophrenia, mood disorder, and other organic disorders.

Other options: 

Option B: Capgras syndrome is a delusion of misidentification. Here, the patient believes that a familiar person has been replaced by an exact double, i.e. an impostor.

Option C: In the delusion of reference, the patient believes that events, objects, or behaviour of others have a special significance to him. For, when he comes across people talking, he might assume that the discussion is about them.

Option D: Othello syndrome is the presence of marked morbid, pathological, or delusional jealousy. The patient here has doubts of infidelity, which is also known as conjugal paranoia. The person holds an abnormal belief that their spouse or partner is being unfaithful. 

Related Pearl: Types of delusions

THE TYPES OF DELUSIONS

Delusion of control

False belief that a person’s will, thoughts, or feelings are being controlled by external forces.

Delusion of grandeur or Megalomania 

Exaggerated conception of one’s importance, power, or identity.

Delusion of infidelity or morbid jealousy or Othello syndrome

False belief that one’s lover is unfaithful. Sometimes called pathological jealousy.

Delusion of love or erotomania

False belief that another person is in love with them. In De Clerambault syndrome, the woman believes that a man, frequently older and of higher status, is in love with her.

Delusion of misidentification 

Capgras syndrome: Belief that a familiar person has been replaced by an exact double i.e. an impostor.

Fregoli syndrome: Person holds a delusional belief that different people are in fact a single person who changes his or her appearance or is in disguise.

Nihilistic delusion 

False belief that oneself, others or the world, is non-existent or about to end. When nihilistic delusion is accompanied by ideas concerning bodily function failure e.g. putrefaction of intestine etc, it is called Cotard syndrome.

Delusion of infestation 

False belief that one is infested with small but visible organisms. As a monosymptomatic delusional disorder, this is called Ekbom syndrome. 

Delusion of persecution

The most common delusion. False belief of being harassed or persecuted.

Delusion of poverty

The person strongly believes they are financially incapacitated.

Delusion of reference

False belief that the behavior of others has a particular and unusual significance, usually of a negative nature. The person may falsely feel that others are talking about them (e.g. the people on television are talking to or about the person).  

Delusion of self-accusation

False feeling of remorse and guilt. Seen in depression with psychotic features.

Related Pearl: Disorders of thought and perception

DISORDERS OF THOUGHT

DISORDER OF STREAM OF THOUGHT

(A) Disorder of tempo

(i) Flight of Ideas

Continuous flow of rapid speech that jumps from topic to topic

  • "I like mangoes, the weather is nice, India is great"

(ii) Retardation of thinking

Slow speed of speech and a prolonged latent period before a response

  • "I went to the market (pause)......... the shop was closed"

(iii) Circumstantialities

Inclusion of irrelevant details and going on in a roundabout manner, but their thought ultimately reaches the answer

  • Doctor: "How did you get that bruise?"

  • Patient: "I woke up and had a cup of coffee, read the newspaper and went for a walk. It was a wonderful day in the park. I returned home and watched the TV. I took a nap in the afternoon after lunch. I slipped and fell in the bathroom. The fall gave me this bruise."

(iv) Clang associations

Jumping from one word to another irrelevant rhyming word

  • I am Sam...I like jam...I travel in a tram"

(B) Disorder of continuity

(i) Perseveration

Repetition of out of context words, phrases, or ideas beyond the point of relevance.

  • Q1. What's your name?: "Rahul"

  • Q2. Where are you from?: "Rahul"

  • Q3. How old are you?: "Rahul"

(ii) Thought blocking

A sudden disruption of thought or a break in the flow of ideas

  • "I went to the market (extreme silence)...................."

DISORDER OF FORM OF THOUGHT

(i) Tangentiality

In response to a question, the patient gives a reply that is appropriate to the general topic but does not answer the question exactly. The speech moves away from the actual answer.

  • Doctor: "Have you had any trouble sleeping lately?"
  • Patient: "I usually sleep in my bed, but now I'm sleeping on the sofa"

(ii) Derailment

A breakdown in both the logical connection between ideas and the overall sense of goal-directedness. The words make sentences, but the sentences do not make sense.

  • "Some people just don't understand why I had breakfast in America during the first world war"

(iii) Neologisms

Bringing in new words that do not exist.

  • The world is not 'gooder' for people like me"

(iv) Desultory thoughts

Speech is grammatically correct, however, sudden unrelated ideas force their way in from time to time.

  • My actual problem is that the people never understand me and my stomach feels like an empty bucket"

(v) Word salad

Using a mixture of unintelligible meaningless words and sentences

  • Tree bus rain food home car tiger"

DISORDER OF POSSESSION OF THOUGHT
A. Thought alienation

(i) Thought insertion

Thoughts are being inserted into the patient's mind and they recognize them as being foreign and coming from without any stimulus

  • "I have repeated thoughts of killing my neighbors and I believe aliens are putting these ideas into my head at night"

(ii) Thought withdrawal

Delusion that someone or something is removing from one's mind and the patient has no power over this.

  • "Lately, I am losing all my memories and I believe that the 'government agents' are stealing them when I go to sleep"

(iii) Thought broadcasting

Belief that one's thoughts are quietly escaping from one's mind and that other people might be able to access them and hear or see them.

  • "I believe my exact thoughts appear on the TV and the internet and I think I can broadcast them globally" 

(iv) Thought echo

Patient hears the 'echo' of his own thoughts in the form of a voice after he has made the thought.

  • "I thought of making a sandwich in the morning and surprisingly a voice, from nowhere, told me to make a sandwich out loud" 

 B. Obsessions and Compulsions

1. Obsessions

Recurrent and persistent thoughts, impulses. or images that cause distress to oneself.

  • Fear of dirt or contamination
  • Fear of becoming ill
  • Constant thoughts of a certain number
  • Need for symmetry or exactness
  • Worry about whether something has been done "right"
  • Forbidden sexual or religious thoughts

2. Compulsions

Repetitive behaviors or actions that the person feels driven to perform in response to an obsession

  • Washing hands
  • Blinking eyes
  • Counting items, such as currency
  • Checking to see if doors are locked
  • Arranging items in a certain way
  • Requiring constant approval from people around them

 
 DISORDER OF CONTENT OF THOUGHT

(i) Phobias

Persistent fear of an object or situation, typically disproportional to the actual danger posed, in which the sufferer goes to great lengths in avoiding it

  • Arachnophobia - fear of spider
  • Barophobia - fear of gravity
  • Cynophobia - fear of dogs
  • Hemophobia - fear of blood
  • Nosocomephobia - fear of hospitals

(ii) Religious preoccupations

Thoughts involving religious themes or subject matter.

  • "I get instructions from God on how to make my country great"

(iii) Ideas of hopelessness

Thoughts of complete despair where the patient strongly believes that the circumstances will never get better for him.

  • "I am never going to pass my final exams, no matter how hard I study"

(iv) Antisocial urges

Thoughts of indulging in some behaviors or actions that harm or lack consideration for the well being of others.

  • "I have these urges to go rob a bank or blackmail my neighbors for their money"

(v) Delusions

False beliefs that are strongly held and unchangeable in the face of refuting evidence and that are not consistent with the person's educational, social and cultural background.

The three main criteria for a belief to be considered a delusion are:

  • Certainty (held with complete confidence)
  • Incorrigibility (not changeable by proof to the contrary)
  • Impossibility or falsity of content (implausible, bizarre or patently untrue)
 DISORDERS OF PERCEPTIONS

  • Illusion: Misinterpretation of real external stimuli.

  • Hallucination: False sensory perception, externally.

  • Pseudohallucination: False sensory perception from within and having an insight.

  • Depersonalization: Feeling as if one is disconnected from reality, feeling detached from one's own thoughts and one's own physical body.

    "I sometimes drift into a dream-like state where I lose contact with my own self"

  • Derealization: Alteration in the perception or experience of the external world so that it seems unreal.

    "The world and everything around is nothing but just a dream"

questions.text: Your co-intern requests the unit chief leave for the weekend, which is denied by the chief. However, on Saturday morning, he complains of severe pain in the abdomen but examination and investigations could not lead to a diagnosis. Which of the following should be considered?
questions.solution:
The scenario described is suggestive of malingering as the patient falsely complained of abdominal pain to avail leave from work.

Malingering is the intentional falsification of physical or psychological symptoms to achieve some practical gain such as financial compensation, avoidance of criminal responsibility or military service, or leave from work. Usually, there is an obvious discrepancy between the complaints and objective findings. The individual is uncooperative during the evaluation and does not comply with the treatment plan proposed. It can be associated with an antisocial personality disorder. In some circumstances, such as while held captive during a war, it can be an adaptive behavior.

Other options:

Option B: Factitious disorder /Munchausen syndrome is the intentional production of physical symptoms to get medical attention. There is no intention to obtain a practical gain.

Option C: Somatic symptom disorder is characterized by the presence of general and non-delu­sional preoccupation with developing a serious disease for ≥6 months. It is based on the person's misinterpretation of bodily symptoms. These preoccupied thoughts cause significant distress and impairment in one's life.

Option D: Dissociative fugue refers to sudden travel away from home associated with partial or complete memory loss about one's identity.

questions.text: An IT employee, who is frustrated with his boss, shows anger on his wife even for minor issues. This defense mechanism is known as _______.
questions.solution:
The defense mechanism depicted here is known as displacement.

Some of the defense mechanisms:

  • Displacement: Unconscious shifting of emotions, usually aroused by a perceived threat, from an unconscious impulse to a less threatening external object which is then thought to be a source of threat
  • Projection: Unconscious attribution of one's own attitude and urges to another person. Eg: A person dislikes his boss but says that the boss dislikes him.
  • Reaction formation: Unconscious transformation of unacceptable impulses into exactly opposite attitudes, impulses, feelings, or behaviors. Eg: A man is attracted to a woman but shows disgust on seeing the woman to hide his feelings. 
  • Splitting: Unconscious viewing of self or others as good or bad without considering the whole range of their qualities.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old married man who is diagnosed with major depressive disorder nominates his wife as the nominee in his advance directive made according to the Mental Healthcare Act 2017. The wife does not play a role in which of the following conditions?
  1. Access to rehabilitation
  2. Emergency treatment
  3. Discharge planning
  4. Admission of the patient
  5. Appoint a suitable attendant
questions.solution:
The nominee (wife) does not play a role in the emergency treatment of the patient. The advance directive shall not apply to the emergency treatment given to a person who made the advance directive.

The provision by which a patient has the right to choose his caretaker and future course of action in treatment because of illness or incapacity is known as an advance directive. 

It contains instructions from the patient about:

  • how they wish to be treated for their mental illness
  • how they do not want to be treated for their mental illness
  • who is appointed as their nominated representative

Important roles of the nominee:

  • Consider the best interest of the patient
  • Support the views of the patient regarding his decisions 
  • Support the patient in making treatment decisions
  • Access to family or home-based rehabilitation services
  • Applying and planning of discharge of the patient
  • Apply for admission of the patient
  • Appoint a suitable attendant
  • Appeal against violation of rights of the patient

Related Pearl: The Mental Health Care Act, 2017 and The Mental Health Act, 1987

The Mental Health Care Act, 2017, was passed to provide for health care and services for persons with mental illness and to protect, promote and fulfill their rights during the delivery of mental health care.

Its main provisions are:

  • Patient autonomy: The mentally ill patient has the right to make an advance directive about their treatment and their nominated representative.
  • If the mental health professional/care-giver does not wish to follow the advance directive made by the patient, they can send an application to the Mental Health Board to review/alter/cancel the advance directive.
  • Decriminalization of suicide.
  • Mental Health Review Commission and Mental Health Authority set up.

 

The Mental Health Act, 1987:

The Mental Health Act, 1987 deals with the care of the mentally ill, makes provisions with respect to their property and affairs and states the law for psychiatric hospitals .

Important provisions under it for the diagnosis of mental illness are:

  • For the diagnosis of mental illness, an individual can be kept in a psychiatric hospital for 10 days.
  • If the mental health professional needs further time, the magistrate can permit an extension of 10 more days.
  • This extension can be permitted only twice.
  • Thus, an individual can be detained in a psychiatric hospital for a maximum period of 30 days only.
  • If a mentally ill person is detained against these provisions, the responsible authority can be punished with an imprisonment of upto 2 years.

questions.text: A 30-year-old army major is relieved from duty in January and returns home. He lives a normal life until Diwali when the sound of firecrackers startles him and he gets flashbacks of his time at war. Since then, he fears possible attacks on his home. He avoids seeing friends from the Army unit as they remind him of war. He is subsequently brought to the hospital on New Year's Eve by his wife who notices his symptoms worsen. Which of the following conditions is he suffering from?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of delayed post-traumatic stress disorder as the onset of symptoms are greater than six months from the event. 

Post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) is a psychiatric disorder characterized by increased stress and anxiety occurring after a stressful or traumatic event, (e.g., witnessing or being involved in violent accidents, crime, war, assault, kidnapping, natural disaster, life-threatening illness, physical or sexual abuse). 

The predisposing factors for this condition include:

  • Presence of childhood trauma
  • Borderline, paranoid, dependent, or antisocial personality disorder traits
  • Inadequate family or peer support system
  • Female gender
  • Genetic susceptibility to psychiatric illness
  • Recent stressful life changes
  • Recent excessive intake of alcohol

Symptoms of PTSD can be divided into four types:

  • Intrusion symptoms
    • Flashbacks- The individual may act and feel as if the traumatic event is reoccurring 
    • Nightmares of the event
  • Hyperarousal 
    • Increased startle response
    • Insomnia
    • Hypervigilance
    • Difficulty concentrating
    • Reckless and self-destructive behavior
    • Irritability and anxiety
  • Avoidance symptoms:  
    • avoiding memories, thoughts, and feelings of the event
    • avoiding external reminders of the traumatic event
  • Negative cognitions and mood associated with the traumatic event
    • Inability to remember an important aspect of the traumatic event
    • Feelings of depersonalization and derealization
    • Anhedonia
    • Negative emotional state- fear, horror, anger, guilt, or shame

The duration of these symptoms should be > 1 month to label it as PTSD. (Symptom onset at Diwali persisting till New Year - which is typically >1 month later)

Based on the duration between the event and the presentation of symptoms, stress disorder is classified as follows.

Duration Condition
3 days to 1 month Acute stress reaction
More than 1 month Post-traumatic stress disorder
Symptoms occur after 6 months Delayed Post-traumatic stress disorder

Psychotherapies found to be effective for PTSD include exposure therapy, trauma-focused cognitive-behavioral therapy, eye movement desensitization, and abreaction. Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) may be prescribed as first-line treatment.

Other options:

Option B -  Panic disorder includes episodes of acute intense attacks of anxiety accompanied by feelings of impending doom. Generalized anxiety disorder is often confused with panic disorder and can be differentiated by the absence of spontaneous panic attacks.

questions.text: A child is brought to the psychiatrist with complaints of recurrent nightmares involving a monster. When asked about the monster in the dream he says that the monster wears the belt that his dad uses to beat him with and carries a stick that his teacher carries. The monster also yells at him as his mother does. Which of the Freudean interpretation of dreams does this signify?
questions.solution:
The following clinical scenario where several unconscious fears are combined into a single image in the dream content follows the mechanism of condensation.

According to the Interpretation of dreams written by Sigmund Freud, dreams represent unconscious wishes or thoughts which are not accepted by the conscious mind. They manifest through the following mechanisms:

  • Symbolism: Representation of highly charged ideas or objects through innocent images that are in some way connected. 
  • Displacement: Transfer of mental energy from one object to a substitute or symbolic representation of the object. 
  • Condensation: Mechanism by which multiple unconscious wishes combine into a single image. Converse to it is called irradiation or diffusion, where, one unconscious wish gets distributed into multiple images. 
  • Projection: Attributing one’s own unacknowledged feelings to others. 
  • Secondary elaboration: Process by which the ego organizes illogical, bizarre and absurd images into a more coherent form in dreams.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man who lost his wife 2 months back was brought to the OPD. He complains of feeling low whenever he thinks of his wife and has lost interest in daily activities. He does not have any suicidal ideations and experiences moments where he is motivated to move on. He mentioned that he had heard his wife's voice once while alone at home. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The scenario described here, after the loss of a loved one, is a normal grief reaction. This reaction also occurs with other losses, such as the loss of a body part, or, for younger people with a miscarriage or abortion.

Normal grief or bereavement begins immediately or a few months after the loss of a loved one. It is characterized initially by shock and denial. The signs and symptoms include feeling low, constant thoughts about the deceased, crying, irritability, and difficulties with sleep and concentration. However, the symptoms are not as pervasive as in depression. The patient's motivation to move on also points in favor of normal grief. The functional impairment is mild.

Transient hallucinations related to the deceased person (hearing the voice of the deceased occasionally) occur in certain cases of normal grief reaction and are not considered psychosis.

Other options: 

Option B: Psychotic depression is characterized by the presence of delusions and/or hallucinations along with the symptoms of depression. It reflects a poor prognosis

Option C: Delusional disorder - Delusions are false beliefs, that are firmly held despite objective and obvious contradictory proof. Other members of the culture do not share this belief. This is the most common manifestation of delusional disorders. In this scenario, the husband is aware of the fact that his wife is dead.

Option D: Schizophrenia is defined by the presence of psychosis (hallucinations, delusions, and disorganized speech) for more than 6 months. Mood symptoms are absent or present for only brief periods.

questions.text:
Which of the following factors play a role in the formation of gender roles?
  1. Experience with people
  2. Chromosomes
  3. Explicit instructions
  4. Secondary sexual characters
  5. External genitalia
questions.solution:
The factors that play a role in building gender roles are experiences with people and explicit instructions.

Gender role:

Acts that a person says or does to disclose himself or herself as having the status of boy or man, girl or woman is called gender role. It is not established at birth. It is built up through the following factors :

  1. Experiences with people which are unplanned and casual that aids in learning
  2. Instructions and inculcation from the people around them. 
  3. One's own interpretation of their role.

Other options: Chromosomes, secondary sexual characters, and external genitalia are factors influencing gender identity and sexual identity. 

Gender identity is an individual’s sense of maleness or femaleness. It results from the clues derived from experience with family, peers, and culture e.g., physique, body shape, different ways of handling male and female infants by parents. It is established by the age of 2 or 3 years. It also depends on the individual's external genitalia and an influence by genetics that is physiologically active by the sixth week of fetal life.

The pattern of a person's biological sexual characteristics is known as sexual identity. These are influenced by factors such as chromosomes, external genitalia, internal genitalia, hormones, gonads, and secondary sex characteristics.

questions.text: Which of the following can you assess by a digit span test?
questions.solution:
The digit span test is used for testing attention and immediate recall.

Related Pearl: Tests for evaluating attention, concentration and memory

Memory:

Memory is of 3 types:

  • Immediate memory and recall are usually tested by digit span/ digit repetition test.
    • Digit span test: Digits spelled at the rate of 1 digit per second. It is of two types: Digit forward and Digit backward.
    • Digit forward: Reproduction of increasingly longer digits. E.g., Examiner says 2 - 4 –8 –1 –5 –7 - 9. The person has to repeat in the same order 2 – 4 – 8 –1 –5 –7 –9.
    • Digit backward: Reproduction of longer digits in the backward direction. Eg: Examiner says 2 - 4 –8 –1 –5 –7 - 9. The person has to repeat it backward. 9 -7 -5 -1 -8- 4- 2.
    • The above tests should be stopped when there are 2 successive failures. Hence 2 skips are not allowed.
  • Recent memory: Ask them how they reached the hospital or what they ate for breakfast.
  • Remote memory: Relevant questions from the past like close relative's birth dates. 

Attention:

  • Is the patient's attention easily aroused and sustained?
  • Digit span test.

Concentration:

  • Is the patient easily distractable or can they concentrate?
  • Serial subtraction test: Minimum of five subtractions done serially is taken into account
  • Count backward from 20.
  • Enumerate the months in reverse order.

questions.text: A runway model was presented with anemia, swollen parotid glands, and low BMI. Her husband says that she does not eat well and is always worried about gaining weight. Which of the following is the most common psychiatric comorbidity that you would expect to find in this patient?
questions.solution:
The most common psychiatric comorbidity to expect in this patient with anorexia nervosa is depression. 

Anorexia nervosa is a disease characterized by self-induced starvation, fear of gaining weight, and uncontrolled wish to become thin. It is divided into:

  • Restrictive: Losing weight by reducing the food intake.
  • Binge/purge: Losing weight by purging after binge eating along with diet. 

It is commonly seen associated with depression, social phobia, obsessive-compulsive disorder, and mania. Depression is the most common psychiatric comorbidity in these patients. Other features seen are swollen parotid glands, anemia, dehydration, etc.

Patients with a weight 20% less than expected weight for height should be considered for hospitalization. Psychotherapy consists of cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT), dynamic psychotherapy, and family therapy. Pharmacological agents are not the first-line treatment but cypro­heptadine, amitriptyline, clomipramine, pimozide, and chlorproma­zine show some improvement in these patients.

Other options:

Option B: Social phobia is the fear of being embarrassed or humiliated in front of others. Anxiety disorders, mood disorders, substance-related disorders, and bulimia nervosa are the other comorbidities seen. 

Option C: Obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) includes intrusive thoughts, preoccupations, and compulsions which cause distress to the patient. Depression is the most common comorbidity seen. The frequency of presenting patterns of OCD is an obsession with contamination > pathological doubt > aggressive or sexual act >need for symmetry. Management includes CBT and SSRIs. 

Option D: Panic disorder is a feeling of sudden intense fear when there is nothing to fear. Social phobia, generalized anxiety disorder, post-traumatic stress disorder, OCD etc are the other comorbidities seen.

questions.text: During couples therapy, the wife complains about the husband's behavior during intercourse. The husband says that he does not obtain pleasure unless he is yelled at and beaten. Which of the following paraphilias does the husband suffer from?
questions.solution:
The person in question is sexually aroused by being humiliated and injured by the sexual partner. This is highly suggestive of sexual masochism.

Paraphilias or perversions are sexual stimuli or acts that are deviations from normal sexual behaviors but are necessary for some people to experience arousal and orgasm.

Sexual arousal and pleasure stemmed from being humiliated, beaten, bound, or made to suffer is a paraphilia known as sexual masochism. This is a disorder that is widely seen in men rather than women. Moral masochism involves a need to suffer but is not accompanied by sexual fantasies. Another specific diagnosis that falls under masochism is autoerotic asphyxiation/asphyxiophilia. This is the act of achieving or heightening sexual arousal as a result of constriction of the airway or restriction of breathing encompasses asphyxiophilia.

Other options :

Option A: Frotteurism is when a person receives sexual gratification by touching or rubbing their genitalia against a non-consenting person. This behavior often occurs in busy and crowded places like buses. It is predominantly described in men.

Option C: When the sexual focus is on a particular object which is associated with the human body (a shoe for example), the paraphilia is known as fetishism. This is found mostly in men. The object of desire usually plays a part during masturbation or sexual intercourse.

Option D: Sexual arousal obtained from the physical or psychological suffering of another person is known as sexual sadism. It is commonly seen in males with the onset before the age of 18. Hereditary predisposition and a history of sexual abuse may be contributory factors to developing sexual sadism.

Other important paraphilic disorders include:

  • Exhibitionism involves the urge to expose genitals to a stranger or unsuspecting person.
  • Pedophilia involves recurrent intense sexual urges or arousal by children less than 13 years of age over a period of at least 6 months.
  • Voyeurism, also called scopophilia, involves an urge to watch an unsuspecting person naked or in sexual activity.
  • Transvestism refers to fantasies and sexual urges to dress in opposite-gender clothing.
  • Telephone and computer scatologia involves obscene phone calling or sending of videos and images to an unsuspecting recipient.
  • Necrophilia is an obsession with obtaining sexual gratification from dead bodies.
  • Zoophilia involves having the urge to involve in sexual activity like intercourse, masturbation, or oral-genital contact with an animal.
  • Coprophilia refers to the sexual pleasure associated with a desire to defecate on the partner, to be defecated on, or to eat feces (coprophilia).
  • Urophilia refers to the sexual pleasure associated with the desire to urinate on a partner or to be urinated on.
  • Hypoxyphilia is the desire to achieve an altered state of consciousness secondary to hypoxia while experiencing orgasm. They may use volatile nitrite or nitrous oxide to produce hypoxia.
